--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> >So said Dave Astels on 2003-07-24 --------------------

> >Another option would be to pass a clean instance to the command 
> >line parser, which then acts as a builder.. calling setters on the
> >instance.  Then you can pass in a mock to be built.. with 
> >expectations as to *how* it will be built.
> 
> Hello! Ding ding ding.... that's nice.

Glad you like it.

> 1. Put the sets on an interface.

Exactly.

> 2. Expose get/set on Test Implementation and submit it to the 
> builder. This tests that the builder calls the interface's sets 
> correctly.
> 
> 3. Don't expose get on Production Implementation because the outside
>  world doesn't need them.

Actually you don't need getters at all.  Mock the interface, and set
expectations on the set calls.  Then pass that into the
builder/parser.  You don't need to capture the args other than to
compare them with what was expected.

Dave
